headline: Rep. Jordan: Obama DOJ wanted Clinton to win the election
subHeadline: Calls intensify for special prosecutor after release of Clinton-Lynch tarmac meeting emails; congressman reacts on 'Your World'

utterances.speaker: TRISH REGAN, GUEST HOST
utterances.sentences: Let's get reaction right now from Ohio Republican Congressman Jim Jordan, a member of the House Judiciary Committee. utterances.speaker: TRISH REGAN, GUEST HOST
utterances.utterance: Let's get reaction right now from Ohio Republican Congressman Jim Jordan, a member of the House Judiciary Committee. Good to have you here, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: REP. JIM JORDAN, R-OHIO
utterances.utterance: Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: So, you would actually like to see a special prosecutor in this. You don't -- you don't like the idea Loretta Lynch was out there using an e-mail that wasn't actually her?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Well, right. If you're just talking about golf, if you're just talking about your grandkids, why do you need to use a pseudonym and a special e-mail account? It is interesting, Trish, that the meeting took place with former President Clinton the day before the Benghazi select committee report was due to come out, two days before Secretary Clinton was to be interviewed by the FBI. And we're all supposed to believe this is coincidence, it just happened, and all they talked about was golf and grandkids? I mean, no one buys that. That to me is a concern, and that is why we have called for a special counsel to look into this and a host of other issues surrounding Mr. Comey and Ms. Lynch.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: Congressman, there are some people that feel like, OK, this is yesterday's news. In other words, she didn't win. Donald Trump is now president. Let's move on. And even Donald Trump himself seemed to sound like he didn't want to go after Hillary Clinton once he had taken office. But now we are in a situation where they are going after him and the -- with the whole special investigation. And it kind of feels like, in some ways, this might be more appropriate, given the level of vitriol they have been directed at him?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: No, it's not -- it is not yesterday's news. It's the fact that the people -- treatment under the law, and that was not what Secretary Clinton got. She got special treatment. She got different standard than what you or I would get. Second, based on Mr. Comey's testimony a few weeks back, where he indicated, at the direction of the United States attorney general, he then, the FBI director, went out and misled the American people when he called the investigation a matter and not an investigation. As I said in committee 10 days ago, the last time I checked, he wasn't the director of federal bureau of matters. He's the Federal Bureau of Investigation. So, why call it something different? Why would the attorney general instruct the FBI director to mislead the American people? And why would she meet with the president, former president, just days before the secretary is supposed to be interviewed by the FBI? I think the answer is obvious. They wanted Clinton -- the Justice Department, the Obama Justice Department, wanted Clinton to win the election. Remember, this all happens in the larger context of running for president.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: So, it is a different kind of conclusion perhaps. Congressman, it seems there are a lot of questions here, a whole lot of questions. And as much as people would like to move on kind of for the health of the country, and you got a new president, and Hillary Clinton is in the past, I hear you...

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: ... in that this kind of stuff cannot be allowed. And so there are -- there are questions that need to be answered and there are things that need to be addressed.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: What's that?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Yes. The Justice Department shouldn't be misleading the American public, and that is exactly what they did. And you have to ask the question, why? And it seems to me, when you asked the question why, it's obvious. They were trying to help Clinton win.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, Congressman, I do have to hand it to her on the alias, though. Elizabeth Carlisle has kind of a nice ring to it.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: It does make it harder for journalists, though, when you're trying to get those e-mails from Loretta Lynch.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: Because it turns out, you can get all the Loretta Lynch you want, but you are going to not get the Elizabeth Carlisle.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: Let me turn to North Korea with you, obviously, very big story today out of The Washington Post.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: What -- what are we going to do here? This has gotten to the point where we're going to need to do something. And, Congressman, I don't if all those sanctions, even within China on board, are ever going to work.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: Yes. No, we applaud the Trump administration and Ambassador Haley for the work that they did on the sanctions. I think that is certainly the right direction to move. I know the Trump administration is trying to work with China to exert more pressure on North Korea in that part of the world. But this is serious. I know this White House and our foreign policy experts are taking it for the very serious matter that it is. We will have to wait and see, but let's hope that this individual, golly, who runs North Korea can tone it down a little bit, and some of this has the kind of impact that we all hope it does.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: Do you expect that China is actually going to be able to enact any kind of influence here, or this just sort of ceremonious?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: I mean, we will see. But I have always thought that the idea that our administration, the Trump administration, engaged with China and urges them to get move involved and to get control of this, exert some influence on North Korea, I have always thought that was a smart move and the right move. Again, we will just have to see.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.utterance: All right, Congressman, good to have you here. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.utterance: You bet. Take care, Trish.
